Dec 22, 2016

Why I Don’t Want An Ordinary Job

It’s not because I’m lazy, it’s because I’m much more driven than most even while enduring a developmental disability my whole life.

“Nothing productive takes place when everything is the same.

Neurological differences similarly drive the engine of

society and create the contrasts between hot and cold that

generate new ideas. Impairments in one area can lead to

advantages in others, and it is these differences that drive progress.”

  • Matthew H. Schneps, “The Advantages of Dyslexia”, Scientific American Mind Issue February 2015

First of all, I’d like to start out with a statistic: Unemployment and underemployment are extremely common for people with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), so common in fact that it’s basically unethical. Amy Harmon, who writes for The New York Times, states that people with ASD typically disappear from public view after leaving school. Only 1 in 10 people with ASD have even part-time employment. Most people with ASD live either in state-supported homes or they live unemployed or underemployed at home with parents or relatives, even for those who graduate from college or university.

Many on the spectrum have these challenges:

  1. Lack of eye contact and confusing social interactions
  2. Ask too many questions
  3. Lack of flexibility on tasks
  4. Literal interpretations of language

Web-based survey from the Amherst H. Wilder Foundation (Source: https://www.stthomas.edu/workplaceforum/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/S1-A-handout1.pdf)

  • Web-based survey from the Amherst H. Wilder Foundation (Source: https://www.stthomas.edu/workplaceforum/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/S1-A-handout1.pdf)
  • Ratings of Workplace Support and Inclusivity
  • ENCOURAGED TO BE MYSELF AT WORK: 77% agreed/strongly agreed, 24% disagreed/strongly disagreed
  • TREATED EQUALLY AND FAIRLY: 76% agreed/strongly agreed, 25% disagreed/strongly disagreed
  • WORK CLIMATE IS INCLUSIVE: 64% agreed/strongly agreed, 36% disagreed/strongly disagreed
  • WORKPLACE HAS A SUPPORTIVE CULTURE: 62% agreed/strongly agreed, 38% disagreed/strongly disagreed
  • EMPLOYER ACTIVELY RECRUITS AND HIRES: 22% agreed/strongly agreed, 78% disagreed/strongly disagreed

While the statistics towards workplace support and inclusivity for autistic people has gotten significantly better and is overwhelmingly positive in terms of being encouraged to express individuality at work, fair and equal treatment, inclusive work climate, and supportive work culture, there is a very blatant case that there is enormous discrimination against autistic people in hiring. The VAST majority of autistic people don’t get hired just because they are autistic. I know this not just through research and statistics but I can back it up with my own personal experience of applying for jobs. I kept either being told or implied to by human resources people that I have great skills, but I’m “overqualified”. I understand if this could happen in one or two or three jobs, but when you’ve been told this by every single job you’ve applied to over the span of four years, the problem’s not you. It’s clearly the system. It’s very clearly discrimination. They’re nonverbally judging you for being autistic. It’s like not being hired if you’re not white, not male, or not heterosexual. It’s absurd.

And these are entry-level jobs I’m talking about!!!! Entry level jobs! Retail and restaurant jobs! Clearly I have felt that begging someone to give me a job so that I can shut up, do robotic drudgery, and be given only enough money to live is NOT the kind of work I ever want to do. They are cruel to autistic people and I as an autistic person will never subject myself to such cruel treatment just to earn a paycheck. In fact I’ve learned through my research that retail and restaurant jobs are among the worst kinds of jobs for people with autism are cashiers, cooks, waiters/waitresses because of too much sensory input, the social quirkiness of most autistic people, inability to handle large crowds, problems with showing emotions, and the need for certain things to be in a certain way. The tech industry and internet-related jobs on the other hand are truly a godsend for autistic people because it allows them to be themselves.

Though I’m great at emotional expression, I myself wouldn’t be able to handle the sensory overwhelm that comes with most entry-level and minimum wage work. I am extremely sensitive to both sound and pain. When a noise is too deafening or screeching I am completely disrupted and scattered and lose all track of what I’m doing and what injuries would be only mildly painful for some would cause me excruciating pain that I wouldn’t be able to tolerate. Many people with autism are also highly sensitive to bright lights, though I am less so and can tolerate it better. I also can’t really do banter well unless it is something I’m interested in or share with another person. I would also hate to have my time managed by anyone but me, as it’s completely disruptive to my peace of mind. Certainly I don’t want an employer managing my time because I wouldn’t like it and I hate being ordered around. I like to only take orders from myself because I like doing projects for people and for myself when they’re on my terms and meaningful to me and if you don’t like that, then I won’t waste my time or energy with you.

Being on the spectrum myself, I have endured all of these challenges as well. While I no longer have problems with eye contact and flexibility on tasks and (mostly) on literal interpretations of language, I’m honestly too much of a questioner and asking lots of questions is the way I am. Also many kinds of social interactions were extremely confusing to me and while I’ve significantly improved, I still don’t see the point of some kinds of social interactions, for example, the fact that you should act friendly towards people you don’t know (which in many countries to inform my U.S. readers in particular would be looked at as really creepy), and honestly I would only feel comfortable acting friendly towards them if we were in a professional interaction or in a social activity where I had common interests and values I could share with them. I see no point in wasting my time with people irrelevant to my goals and interests because my brain doesn’t see any concrete reason for it (for neurotypical (people with typical brain wiring) out there you can think of my thought processes as kind of like Spock but not exactly).

I must also say that I have ASD since birth and was diagnosed at age 4, being told by my preschool teacher after refusing to follow class directions that I wouldn’t be able to write my own name, read, cut with scissors, or function in society simply because I wanted to do my own thing rather than what everybody else was doing. Thus the way I have always been was making a sometimes stubborn commitment to doing my own thing. I have always had a tendency for nonorthodoxy and a strong resistance to authority. Because of this, freelancing and entrepreneurship and self-employment in general have always been the most appealing types of employment to me and I didn’t like anything else.

When I had spent my whole life trying to figure out what kind of work would be the most meaningful and purposeful for me to do, I got accused of being lazy simply because I didn’t want to go out and get a job like everyone else. Here’s another thing, I felt emotionally sick when I tried applying for jobs that I only wanted to have because of the money. A job that helps me work towards developing the skills I want and fulfilling my purpose on the other hand, I would feel really empowered by. What I’m looking for is people to help me in my professional development, to give me the chance to fully and authentically express myself the way I see fit, and the chance to grow and develop into my full potential.

Also, I really dislike job interviews and don’t want to endure another again. That is not how I want to get a job. I’d rather be hired or have work based on my actual skill-set and set of values rather than on just personality alone. I want to get into amazing jobs based on my intuition rather than just money-hunting alone. I am a vessel for a greater cause that I will fight for my entire life: the equal rights of autistic people and in general for all human beings, especially the oppressed and disenfranchised and marginalized, and the freedom for them to be able to do whatever they want whenever they want without being told by society what they should do.

My personal values are community, adventure, service, freedom, empowerment, and lifelong learning. I seek to always honor those values in whatever I do and keep my integrity.

Sources:

Autism Spectrum Disorders in the Workplace
Boston University and other colleges and universities have increased the accessibility of higher education to students…www.bu.edu
What Is Autism?
The world is unpredictable and disorderly. Sometimes your train is late; sometimes it rains when it's not supposed to…www.newyorker.com
